The RMP/PSM Manual contains the policies and procedures used at the Broco Terminal to assure continued compliance with the EPA CAP and OSHA PSM regulations. Most of the sections in this RMP/PSM Manual follow a standard format that includes the purpose, responsibilities, procedures, and documents. 

Employees are required to review relevant elements of the procedures in this RMP/PSM program. This plan is available on-site for employee review. Recommendations to improve this document’s accuracy or effectiveness can be directed to the Terminal Manager.

The goal of the RMP/PSM program, including supporting policies and procedures, is to prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur.

The 1990 Amendments to the Clean Air Act (CAA) required EPA to issue a rule specifying the type of actions to be taken by facilities to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals into the atmosphere and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment.

Covered facilities also must submit registration information (RMP Submission) to EPA no later than June 21, 1999 or the date on which the facility first has more than a threshold quantity in use or stored at the site, whichever is later. Covered facilities are also required to re-submit their Risk Management Plans every five years. The RMP Submission provides an electronic summary of the facility’s Risk Management Plan.

Covered facilities also must continue to implement the management practices documented in this plan and update their plans periodically or when processes change, as required by the rule.

Broco Terminal, LLC handles, manufactures, uses in a process or stores any of the toxic or flammable substances listed in 40 CFR §68.130 above the specified threshold quantities, the facility is required to develop and implement a Risk Management Plan (RMP). The Chemical Accident Prevention rule was issued and is administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). This rule, “Chemical Accident Prevention (CAP) Provisions” (Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)), applies to a wide variety of facilities that handle, manufacture, store or use toxic and/or flammable substances.

Broco Terminals, LLC, owned by Broco Energy, Inc., has the capacity to store 214,200 pounds of propane at the distribution facility located at 168 Hale Street Haverhill, Massachusetts. The facility provides wholesale propane distribution to the local home heating, industrial, and commercial markets.

The Broco Terminal is required to address requirements of the CAP regulations because they exceed the 10,000-pound propane threshold outside of internal fuel and/or retail sales. The terminal is a wholesale distributor of propane, and is not subject to the exemptions extended to propane facilities in accordance with the Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act of 2000.

The regulated substances stored and distributed are propane The propane is brought into the Hale Street facility by up to (1) 33,000-gallon railcars, offloaded into (2) 30,000-gallon tanks (each), that are connected by manifold fixed piping systems.

NOTE: Administrative controls limiting the amount of propane stored in the railcars is not considered as Broco has limited control over railcar filling operations. A maximum of 85% of capacity (administratively controlled by Broco personnel) is stored in the 30,000-gallon tanks.
